Here are the steps to solve this problem:
First, recognize that the points $(2, -5)$, $(p, -14)$, and $(p+2, -17)$ lie on the same straight line. This implies they have the same slope.
Calculate the slope of the line using the points $(2, -5)$ and $(p, -14)$. Use the slope formula $m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}$, substituting $(x_1, y_1) = (2, -5)$ and $(x_2, y_2) = (p, -14)$.
Calculate the slope of the line using the points $(p, -14)$ and $(p+2, -17)$. Use the same slope formula, substituting $(x_1, y_1) = (p, -14)$ and $(x_2, y_2) = (p+2, -17)$.
Since the slope between any two points on a line must be the same, set the two slope expressions found in steps 2 and 3 equal to each other and solve for $p$.
Substitute the value of $p$ back into either slope equation to verify or adjust as necessary.
Use the point-slope form of the line equation y - y1 = m(x - x1) with one of the points and the slope calculated to find the linear equation in terms of $y$ and $x$.
Substitute $x=13$ into the linear equation to find the value of $y$ when $x = 13$, which gives the value of $q$.
Add the values of $p$ and $q$ to find the value of $p + q$.
Round $p + q$ to the nearest tenth as required.
Following these steps will help determine the precise values of $p$ and $q$, allowing for the calculation of $p + q$.
